title: I salute this woman! She has went through hell just to get an education and be equal. She was shot in...

attachments.displayName:
I salute this woman! She has went through hell just to get an education and be equal. She was shot in the head and lived to tell the tale of that brutality! When will women REALLY be free in this world?
There are men on G+ right now who would agree to shoot this beautiful girl again for her so called atrocities against her religion and the men in her country who are hard core traditionalists.

object.content:
I salute this woman! She has went through hell just to get an education and be equal. She was shot in the head and lived to tell the tale of that brutality! When will women REALLY be free in this world?
There are men on G+ right now who would agree to shoot this beautiful girl again for her so called atrocities against her religion and the men in her country who are hard core traditionalists.

annotation:
Bless this woman, you have my respect and admiration  ♥♥♥  You are doing now for your area of the world what the women in my part of the world already did in the 1920s.

I am thankful every day to Early American Women, their efforts and sacrifices are the reason women in the West have progressed as far as we have today in terms of Equal Rights.   I'm glad to see women in the East are finally standing up for their rights too - it starts with one and I hope to see more.  After all, it is all up to them - it's their world and how they want to make it.

object.content: Well is obvious, change has to come from within, women in the east have to want to change things..
It would help, though, if more of the Women of the West supported the Women of the East.
The problem is that a lot of women of the west want to support them in their terms..
Why do you consider that a problem +Sordatos Cáceres ?    IMO it is up to them to fight their own "battles", if they chose to do so.

I don't recall the women who made those changes in the west having to do so with a loaded weapon to there heads on a regular bases. I could be wrong. Brave though they still were, I'm sure they needed some assistance in the beginning.

+Mark Powell  I read up on our history and yes they did have guns held to their heads, also were severely beaten in public, thrown in jails and mental institutions where they were repeatedly raped and beaten - just to name a few of the atrocities early American women experienced fighting for their rights.   They went thru hell and still fought on.
I am curious what you guys think women of the West should actually be doing in terms of this topic?   I applaud them and wish them all the best.
Thank you for the correction.
Help with emotional  and financial support I guess. Women in those circumstances must feel very alone and isolated. Any support that a women would normally want I suppose.
It's a shame, she didn't win the Nobel Peace Prize!

+Mark Powell  Financial support won't be happening, at least not from me.  I'm struggling just to keep a roof over my own head!    I would gladly offer emotional support if the women there had some way of connecting with us here, but they seem to be kept pretty isolated  :-(

+Donna Zachare It's a problem more generally with faux-supporters of reform, but it applies here. We need to all celebrate and support the small victories knowing that it builds a cascade. A person that diminishes or refuses to help because just adding color to the Burqas is not "going far enough" is as much an impediment to progress as a person that quietly disagrees with change or ignores the plight.
How about passing on lessons learned from all that knowledge of the suffrage movement. What applies today to their movement that would encourage and equip them to overcome?

Could you put that into simpler language +Werner Hahn, I'm not exactly sure what you're trying to say with the above comment.  

Are you trying to guilt trip me because I'm not rushing out and sending $$$ to "the cause"?  If that's the case, feel free to send your own $$$, I'm sure they would appreciate it!    :-D
+Mark Powell  That's a great idea, now go out and do it!  I'd be interested to see how you manage to pass along those lessons.  :-D

+Donna Zachare In my opinion at the very least not berate them for not embracing "western" values or victimize them when they chose to, for example, wear the scarf over their heads or follow Islam (regardless on my opinions on religion in general)


I'm not saying you do those things, just that I've seen many "allies" that do it..

Oh I'm doing it now, I'm helping a 19 year old young woman in the Philippines step away from her parents abuse and into a job and college. It's challenging to communicate across cultures and languages but it's worth it.

+Donna Zachare No guilt trips. I think you asked what the West can do to help, this is just one answer among many. People often get frustrated with small changes, but to allow them to get in the way of support is very counterproductive. 

P.S. - That young woman is amazing.
Fear is a dangerous attribute to base your decisions on.

I hope the best for them in their struggles, as is the intent of this post - Well Wishes - as I also hope the best for us in the US as we go thru our own struggles.  

My main focus these days is jobs, if I don't find one soon my personal "opportunities to think differently" (aka challenges, crises) will be just beginning.  So I'll keep my focus where it's needed the most - in my own backyard.    :-D

+Sordatos Cáceres I have never seen, in person, someone berate an Eastern woman for holding on to her Arabic identity.  I have, however, seen many posts on social sites berating American women for their choice of clothing, which IMO is an attempt at suppression here.   Have you personally, actually, seen anyone do it (be abusive towards a woman for her clothing choice)?

+Michael Silk  not sure who your addressing your comment to?

+Mark Powell  That is awesome!   We've got 5 20-somethings in my family right now that we've all been trying to carry while they struggle to support themselves - it's tough out there right now!

Only on blogs, because, admittedly where I am there are not many Muslims, and the people that do or had emigrated from Middle East tend to assimilate the local culture more or less (with the exception of the occasional reference to their heritage) more over, most of them (or the ones I have seen) come from Christian families not Muslim..

I understand what you are saying +Donna Zachare I meant no criticism towards you for prioritizing your goals. I wish you the best and hope you are all able to land jobs that meet your needs. Sorry I can't do more than offer verbal support.
They opt for the illusion because the reality is too bleak to bear.
*than

+Donna Zachare My point was that more attention needs to be paid to this sort of thing. Women in Saudi Arabia can't vote, can't drive and aren't allowed to leave the country without a male relative as a Chaperone. But at least they aren't regularly gang raped like in some of the less sophisticated Middle Eastern countries.

There is also a huge problem with Human Trafficking in that part of the world. I feel like, and perhaps I am wrong but this is how I feel, that some members of the Left hesitate to point that sort of thing out because they would rather bash the West for the Atlantic Slave Trade - which started well after the Eastern version and ended well before.

+Michael Pate if that is your chosen "cause" then go do  something about it, rather than being an armchair activist.   Volunteering other's  time, labor and money, while not expending any of your own is just an empty gesture IMO.

There's so much that needs to be done in this world, and I've learned not to spread myself too thin and try and "do it all".   I've also learned to chose my battles, and do what's most important to me personally.   

I'll applaud the women of the East for any progress they make, and hope their efforts continue to progress.  :-D
Man see's the opportunity to further her slavery.

+Michael Pate I'll take that one up. I understand why you feel that way, but I think it's associated with an attentional bias, negativity bias, and problem of imperfect expression of preferences. 

Let's be blunt. 95% of Americans and Westerners do not condone middle eastern woman's rights as they stand. The other 5% can and should be ignored (and their ideas contained where possible).  This is true on almost any topic of conversation by the way. 

The subset of the Left you mention is included in that 95%, and they chose to spend time discussing the effects of the Atlantic Slave Trade. These are not incompatible or illogical or malicious. It is an issue of not having an infinite capacity to express their attitudes. So they make preferential choices on which they will discuss.

They chose to talk about the ones they feel are most pertinent to their lives. Just like most people in the U.S. will discuss the debt ceiling crisis, but rarely point out the Greek economy which is in much worse shape. We could have strong opinions about Greece, but we talk about those that are most pertinent to our lives.

The regional bias is not the only one that exists. One could easily accuse a Westerner that cares more about the plight of "people on the other side of the world, when there are people starving in California." Yet, they are expressing a rationale choice to focus on the greatest harm instead of the nearest one. 

It is amazingly easy to dismiss or insult the preference of another, much harder to disassociate the small pain one feels at the clash of preferences in the moment and take on both issues with solemnity. 

As for the reference to negativity and attentional bias, that's not meant as a criticism, just something to be aware of. When people are talking about the Atlantic slave trade and its effects on modern society, it is easy for people to feel criticized for the action of another because they share a certain heritage or physical traits with the other person that is being criticized. An unnecessary and false pack mentality of sorts. And those negative feelings tend to outweigh positive experiences and create lasting negative impressions of that subset of the left. I get that. Especially when people in that subset are not uber careful about their syntax and don't make the distinctions clear.

But it is still not true that they are hesitant to point out the terrible acts committed in other countries against woman. At least not the 95% of the subset that are worth discussing.

Apologies for length, I tend to write these things in stream of conscience and more for my own clarity than others. Cheers!
She will do all for the kings.

+Mark Powell  Thank you, and I don't ask for any more other than that much welcomed verbal support.  :-D   When I do contribute to charity it's usually Smile Train, I think those people are really making a difference  ♥
Smile Train is a very cool project.
She is capable of everything.
+Michael Silk  I still don't get what you're trying to say, but no worries  :-D
He can finally relax.
+Werner Hahn you write very well  :-D
+Donna Zachare too kind. :P
She has that special idealism that the young often have but it her family were not behind her we would never have heard what she has to say.

title: Google+ List of Comments for an Activity
